abstract.para: This chapter describes how to set up an &nvmeof; host and target.

sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: NVM Express (&nvme;) is an interface standard for accessing non-volatile storage, commonly SSD disks. &nvme; supports much higher speeds and has a lower latency than SATA.

&nvmeof; is an architecture to access &nvme; storage over different networking fabrics, for example RDMA or &nvme; over Fibre Channel (&fcnvme;). The role of &nvmeof; is similar to iSCSI. To increase the fault-tolerance, &nvmeof; has a built-in support for multipathing. The &nvmeof; multipathing is not based on the traditional &dmmpio;.
The &nvme; host is the machine that connects to an &nvme; target. The &nvme; target is the machine that shares its &nvme; block devices.
&nvme; is supported on &sls; &productnumber;. There are Kernel modules available for the &nvme; block storage and &nvmeof; target and host.
To see if your hardware requires any special consideration, refer to .

sect1.title: Setting Up an &nvmeof; Host
sect1.para: To use &nvmeof;, a target must be available with one of the supported networking methods. Supported are &nvme; over Fibre Channel and RDMA. The following sections describe how to connect a host to an &nvme; target.

sect2.title: Installing Command Line Client
sect2.para: To use &nvmeof;, you need the nvme command line tool. Install it with zypper:

Use nvme --help to list all available subcommands. Man pages are available for nvme subcommands. Consult them by executing man nvme-SUBCOMMAND. For example, to view the man page for the discover subcommand, execute man nvme-discover.

sect2.title: Discovering &nvmeof; Targets
sect2.para: To list available &nvme; subsystems on the &nvmeof; target, you need the discovery controller address and service ID.

Replace TRANSPORT with the underlying transport medium: loop, rdma or fc. Replace DISCOVERY_CONTROLLER_ADDRESS with the address of the discovery controller. For RDMA this should be an IPv4 address. Replace SERVICE_ID with the transport service ID. If the service is IP based, like RDMA, service ID specifies the port number. For Fibre Channel, the service ID is not required.
The &nvme; hosts only see the subsystems they are allowed to connect to.

sect2.title: Connecting to &nvmeof; Targets
sect2.para: After you have identified the &nvme; subsystem, you can connect it with the nvme connect command.

Replace TRANSPORT with the underlying transport medium: loop, rdma or fc. Replace DISCOVERY_CONTROLLER_ADDRESS with the address of the discovery controller. For RDMA this should be an IPv4 address. Replace SERVICE_ID with the transport service ID. If the service is IP based, like RDMA, this specifies the port number. Replace SUBSYSTEM_NQN with the NVMe qualified name of the desired subsystem as found by the discovery command. NQN is the abbreviation for &nvme; Qualified Name. The NQN must be unique.

Alternatively, use nvme connect-all to connect to all discovered namespaces. For advanced usage see man nvme-connect and man nvme-connect-all.

sect2.title: Multipathing
sect2.para: &nvme; native multipathing is enabled by default. To print the layout of the multipath devices, use the command nvme list-subsys. To disable NVMe native multipathing, add nvme-core.multipath=N as a boot parameter.
The command multipath -ll has a compatibility mode and displays &nvme; multipath devices.

sect2.title: Configuration Steps
sect2.para: The following procedure provides an example of how to set up an &nvmeof; target.
The configuration is stored in a tree structure. Use the command cd to navigate. Use ls to list objects. You can create new objects with create.

step.screen: &prompt.nvmetcli;cd ports &prompt.nvmetcli;create 1 &prompt.nvmetcli;ls 1/ o- 1 o- referrals o- subsystems

step.para: Create a new namespace and set an &nvme; device to it:
step.screen: &prompt.nvmetcli;cd namespaces &prompt.nvmetcli;create 1 &prompt.nvmetcli;cd 1 &prompt.nvmetcli;set device path=/dev/nvme0n1 Parameter path is now '/dev/nvme0n1'.
&prompt.nvmetcli;cd .. &prompt.nvmetcli;ls o- nqn.2014-08.org.nvmexpress:NVMf:uuid:c36f2c23-354d-416c-95de-f2b8ec353a82 o- allowed_hosts o- namespaces o- 1

step.para: Allow all hosts to use the subsystem. Only do this in secure environments.
step.screen: &prompt.nvmetcli;set attr allow_any_host=1 Parameter allow_any_host is now '1'.
step.para: Alternatively, you can allow only specific hosts to connect:

step.screen: &prompt.nvmetcli;cd / &prompt.nvmetcli;ls o- / o- hosts o- ports | o- 1 | o- referrals | o- subsystems o- subsystems o- nqn.2014-08.org.nvmexpress:NVMf:uuid:c36f2c23-354d-416c-95de-f2b8ec353a82 o- allowed_hosts o- namespaces o- 1

step.para: Make the target available via RDMA:
step.screen: &prompt.nvmetcli;cd ports/1/ &prompt.nvmetcli;set addr adrfam=ipv4 trtype=rdma traddr=10.0.0.1 trsvcid=4420 Parameter trtype is now 'rdma'. Parameter adrfam is now 'ipv4'. Parameter trsvcid is now '4420'. Parameter traddr is now '10.0.0.1'.

sect2.title: Broadcom
sect2.para: If you are using the Broadcom Emulex LightPulse Fibre Channel SCSI driver, add a Kernel configuration parameter on the target and host for the lpfc module:
Make sure that the Broadcom adapter firmware has at least version 11.4.204.33. Also make sure that you have the current versions of nvme-cli, nvmetcli and the Kernel installed.

To enable a Fibre Channel port as an &nvme; target, an additional module parameter needs to be configured: lpfc_enable_nvmet= COMMA_SEPARATED_WWPNS. Enter the WWPN with a leading 0x, for example lpfc_enable_nvmet=0x2000000055001122,0x2000000055003344. Only listed WWPNs will be configured for target mode. A Fibre Channel port can either be configured as target or as initiator.
